question: Will China launch an antitrust investigation into Intel before April, 2025?
description:
Donald Trump recently imposed a 10% tariff on Chinese imports and eliminated the duty-free exemption for low-value packages, in accordance with his campaing promises. In response, China [filed a complain](https://www.reuters.com/world/china-challenges-trump-tariffs-wto-package-shippers-warn-chaos-2025-02-06/)t with the World Trade Organization, asserting that these U.S. actions are protectionist and violate WTO rules. [Furthermore](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/czj31l4p7vzo), China impemented various retaliatory measures, including

* its own tariffs on American coal, LGN, agricultural machinery, and pick-up trucks
* adding Calvin Klein to their "unreliable entity" list, accusing them of "discriminatory measures against Chinese enterprises"
* export controls on rare metals
* reviving antitrust investigations against Google and Nvidia.

According to the [Financial Times](https://www.ft.com/content/2ec45e79-9502-4ffd-82e8-888d9283c776), China regulators are also considering launching an investigation against Intel.
fine_print: The investigation has to be officially announced, for example via a State Administration for Market Regulation press release.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**TSMC More Likely to Set Up US Packaging Factory than Form Joint Venture with Intel**
A report from Jefferies, a Wall Street investment bank, suggests that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) is more likely to set up a packaging factory in the US than to form a joint venture with Intel. This is due to concerns about antitrust issues with a joint venture. TSMC's packaging factory in the US would eliminate the main bottleneck in its advanced manufacturing process and ensure that the most advanced AI chips are manufactured in the US, aligning with the comments of US Vice President JD Vance. Vance emphasized that the US government is committed to dominating AI chips, AI software technology, and AI rule-making in various areas. He also stated that the Trump administration will ensure that the most powerful AI systems are built in the US using US-designed and manufactured chips. Following Vance's comments, Intel's stock price surged, and rumors emerged that Intel may spin off its semiconductor manufacturing division and form a joint venture with TSMC to drive the development of the US chip manufacturing industry, leading to a 25% increase in Intel's stock price over the past five days. However, Jefferies believes that TSMC is more likely to set up a packaging factory in the US than to form a joint venture with Intel. 'It is more likely that TSMC will set up a packaging factory in the US, which would eliminate the main bottleneck in its advanced manufacturing process and ensure that the most advanced AI chips are manufactured in the US,' said Jefferies. 'This would align with the comments of US Vice President JD Vance, who emphasized that the US government is committed to dominating AI chips, AI software technology, and AI rule-making in various areas.' 
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 14, 2025 01:59 PM
Source:[自由時報電子報](https://ec.ltn.com.tw/article/breakingnews/4951921)

**Chinese Stocks Surge, Apple Plans AI Launch in China, Intel Rumored to Form Joint Venture with TSMC**
The Chinese stock market saw a surge in popular Chinese stocks, with Alibaba rising over 6%, Bilibili rising around 10%, and JD.com rising around 5%. Apple is planning to launch its AI function in China as early as May, in collaboration with Alibaba. The system will analyze and modify Apple's AI models to meet domestic regulatory requirements. Baidu will be the secondary partner for handling other functions. Airbnb reported a 12% increase in revenue and a 4% increase in adjusted profit for the fourth quarter of 2024, exceeding Wall Street's expectations. GameStop is reportedly exploring investments in alternative assets, including cryptocurrencies and Bitcoin. SAP has partnered with Databricks to launch a commercial data cloud. Intel is rumored to be establishing a joint venture with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), with Intel's chip manufacturing facilities potentially being spun off into a new joint venture. Starbucks plans to expand to the Middle East by adding around 500 stores and creating 5,000 jobs over the next five years. The Boring Company, a subsidiary of Elon Musk, has signed a preliminary agreement with the Dubai Roads and Transport Authority to build a 17-kilometer underground high-speed transportation network called the Dubai Ring.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 14, 2025 01:46 PM
Source:[每日经济新闻](https://www.nbd.com.cn/articles/2025-02-14/3752949.html)

**Intel set for biggest weekly gain in 40+ years on potential pact with TSMC By Investing.com**
Intel's shares have surged 25% this week, setting the company up for its biggest weekly gain in over 40 years. The potential partnership with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) is driving the rally, as it could help Intel's operations in the US and fulfill the government's 'Made in America' goal. Analysts at Wolfe Research believe a manufacturing partnership between Intel and TSMC would be the best outcome for Intel, as it would help absorb Intel's fixed costs and drive foundry volume. However, the implementation of such a plan is not without its difficulties, including technical hurdles and antitrust issues. As Wolfe analysts said, 'The technical challenges would undoubtedly be high. But the stakes for INTC are high as well. And the incentive for TSMC would be capacity in the US, elimination of INTC as a competitor, and perhaps some U.S. Government support.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 14, 2025 12:51 PM
Source:[Investing.com](https://www.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/intel-set-for-biggest-weekly-gain-in-40-years-on-potential-pact-with-tsmc-3870312)

**TSMC's Leadership and Resilience: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley Maintain 'Buy' Ratings**
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) has been surrounded by rumors, including the US-China trade war, its partnership with Intel, and potential production capacity issues. Despite these concerns, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley have released reports focusing on six key issues, reaffirming their 'buy' ratings and setting target prices of NT$140 and NT$154 respectively. The six key issues include TSMC's business strategy, its relationship with Intel, potential antitrust implications of their joint venture, production capacity and technology maturity, TSMC's expansion of US production capacity, and potential tariffs. According to the reports, TSMC's advanced process technology is a key competitive advantage, and it is unlikely to license its technology to competitors. Additionally, Morgan Stanley's analyst Chen Jia-yi pointed out that Intel's manufacturing ecosystem, design methods, and production patterns are significantly different from TSMC's, making it difficult for Intel to rapidly expand its foundry business. In terms of potential tariffs, Goldman Sachs' analyst Lü Kūn-lín noted that most semiconductors are sent to downstream customers after being packaged and assembled, so TSMC will not be directly affected by tariffs. TSMC plans to increase its US production capacity by 2028 and 2030, with a total investment of over NT$650 billion in Arizona. Looking ahead, Goldman Sachs expects TSMC to maintain its leading position in the global foundry market, with a market share of over 60% in revenue. With its advanced technology and strong growth prospects in AI, 5G, HPC, and EV, TSMC's valuation is still attractive, with a price-to-earnings ratio of around 10-29 times, and a long-term gross margin of over 53%.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 14, 2025 09:03 AM
Source:[Udnemoney聯合理財網           ](https://money.udn.com/money/story/5607/8548817)

**Sources: Apple plans to launch its AI features in China as early as May 2024, using its own on-device models with Alibaba software to censor or filter AI output**
Apple is facing criticism in Germany over its App Tracking Transparency feature, with the country's antitrust agency releasing a preliminary finding that it uses the feature as a form of self-preferencing. According to the agency, Apple treats tracking permissions requested by third parties differently than its own tracking of iOS users. This has been described as an anticompetitive move disguised as a privacy change. Apple has yet to respond to the criticism, but has been working on launching its AI features in China as early as May 2024, using its own on-device models with Alibaba software to censor or filter AI output.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 14, 2025 03:59 AM
Source:[Techmeme](https://www.techmeme.com/250213/p47)

**Mexico Launches 'Antidumping' Investigation into Chinese Cartoncillo Imports**
The Mexican Ministry of Economy announced on Thursday that it has initiated an 'antidumping' investigation into the importation of cartoncillo from China. The 'antidumping' measure aims to prevent companies from exporting products at low prices, which can harm the local industry. According to the Ministry, the investigation was initiated due to indications that Chinese cartoncillo imports were made at discriminatory prices and posed a threat to the Mexican production branch. The Ministry stated that this measure provides 'an opportune defense to the productive plant against unfair imports' and invites Mexican producers, importers, and exporters, as well as the Chinese government, to present their arguments and evidence in defense of their interests. The investigation period spans from August 2019 to July 2024, during which time complaints were raised about the high volumes of Chinese cartoncillo imports at low prices compared to Mexican production costs.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 13, 2025 08:09 PM
Source:[planoinformativo.com](https://planoinformativo.com/1056070/mexico-abre-investigacion-antidumping-a-importaciones-de-cartoncillo-de-china)

**Opinion | How the trade war could expand beyond tariffs**
The United States' aggressive tariff policies could lead to a broader trade war, with other countries responding in various ways. China has already set retaliatory tariffs on American liquefied natural gas and crude oil, and is considering new antitrust investigations into Intel and Apple. Other countries may use workarounds to avoid US pressure, such as developing alternative infrastructure for global commerce, like the SWIFT system. They may also reduce their holdings of US debt, which could lead to increased interest rates. Additionally, other nations could move to reduce the US dollar's role in trade and lending, as China has been pushing for trade denominations to move from the dollar to the renminbi. 'The broadest category of responses involves workarounds to the ways the United States exerts pressure on other countries,' said the article. 'It's a truth worth remembering as the United States imposes substantially higher tariffs on our trading partners, who have the ability to respond in unanticipated ways.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2025 11:30 AM
Source:[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2025/02/13/trade-war-tariffs-swift-dollar-china/)

**After DeepSeek Shook Wall Street, China's Baidu Gears Up For AI Battle With Next-Gen Ernie 5.0 Launch In Late 2025 China's Baidu Prepares For Ernie 5.0 Launch In The Second Half Of 2025. Offers Current Chatbot Free Of Cost From April - NVIDIA (NASDAQ:NVDA), Baidu (NASDAQ:BIDU)**
Baidu, a Chinese tech giant, is preparing to launch its next-generation AI model, Ernie 5.0, in the second half of 2025. The new model, a 'foundation model,' is expected to show significant improvements in multimodal capabilities, enabling the processing and transformation of various data types, including text, video, images, and audio. Baidu's current chatbot, Ernie, will be available for free to individual users starting in April, along with a free advanced search function. Baidu CEO Robin Li emphasized the importance of persistent investment in data centers and cloud infrastructure, stating, 'The inference cost [of foundation models] basically can be reduced by more than 90% over 12 months.' The launch of Ernie 5.0 comes amid the disruption caused by new entrants like DeepSeek in the AI industry.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2025 08:57 AM
Source:[Benzinga](https://www.benzinga.com/markets/25/02/43685601/after-deepseek-shook-wall-street-chinas-baidu-gears-up-for-ai-battle-with-next-gen-ernie-5-0-launch-in-late-2025)

**China's Antitrust Investigation into NVIDIA: Background, Procedures and Practical Interpretation**
China's antitrust watchdog, the State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR), has launched an investigation into American chipmaker NVIDIA for suspected violations of the Chinese Anti-Monopoly Law (AML). The investigation is related to SAMR's conditional clearance decision regarding NVIDIA's 2020 acquisition of Mellanox Technologies. NVIDIA's ability to meet its supply obligations in mainland China is likely to face challenges due to the U.S. Department of Commerce's export restrictions on certain advanced computing integrated circuits and semiconductor manufacturing equipment. The investigation highlights the growing monopolistic concerns in the global chip industry and the escalating tech tensions between China and the U.S. The case may reach an impasse due to the inherent conflicts between China's AML and U.S. export control regulations, as well as the challenges and uncertainties involved in applying the principle of international comity.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 13, 2025 07:14 AM
Source:[Lexology](https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=12beb217-fb29-4af4-bd65-b761708a0063)

**China strikes back with $14bn in retaliatory tariffs on US goods**
China has imposed retaliatory tariffs on $14 billion worth of US goods, escalating trade tensions with Washington. The move targets US exports such as liquefied natural gas, crude oil, coal, farm equipment, and automotive goods with tariffs between 10% and 15%. Additionally, Beijing has launched an antitrust probe into US tech firms and restricted exports of key rare earth metals crucial for defense and green energy industries. Analysts suggest China may be better prepared for a trade standoff this time, though financial markets had initially hoped for negotiations. The US Trade Representative's upcoming report on China's compliance with a 2020 trade deal, due April 1, could trigger further tensions.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[zwnews.com](https://zwnews.com/china-strikes-back-with-14bn-in-retaliatory-tariffs-on-us-goods/)

**China Launches Antitrust Investigations into Google, Nvidia, and Intel**
China has reopened investigations into Google and Nvidia, and is considering a new investigation into Intel, as part of Beijing's efforts to gain leverage in talks with US President Donald Trump. The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) announced on Tuesday that it had opened an investigation into Google's dominance of the Android operating system and any harm caused to Chinese phone manufacturers such as Oppo and Xiaomi. The regulators also announced a similar antitrust investigation into Nvidia in December, and are now considering a formal review of Intel. According to Liu Xu, a researcher at the National Strategy Institute of Tsinghua University, the investigations 'may be part of China's retaliatory measures' in response to Trump's new tariffs. Xu added that using antitrust investigations as a tool in trade negotiations 'may not be the best way to protect Chinese companies affected by US tariffs, as it would inevitably provoke controversy.' The move comes as tensions between the two global powers continue to escalate, with the US imposing stricter controls on the export of advanced chips to China. 'China is using its regulatory power to push back against the US,' said Xu. 'This is a new chapter in the trade war between the two countries.' The investigation into Google, which was first launched in 2019, was archived for years but was reopened in December, just before Trump's return to the White House. The SAMR visited Google's office in Beijing in January and demanded that the company provide information related to the investigation. 'Google is well welcome to continue growing its business in China,' said a Commerce Ministry official, days before the SAMR announcement. Nvidia, which is being investigated for alleged antitrust violations related to its acquisition of Mellanox Technologies in 2019, has seen its sales in China grow to 13% of its global revenue in the first three quarters of 2024. Intel, which has a significant presence in China, could face significant penalties if found guilty of antitrust violations, including fines linked to its global revenue or loss of access to the Chinese market. 'China is the largest market for Intel, surpassing the US,' said a report. 'The company registered sales of $15.5 billion in China in 2024, representing 29% of its global revenue.'
Original language: es
Publish date: February 05, 2025 07:02 AM
Source:[Diario Financiero](https://www.df.cl/internacional/ft/china-arremete-contra-gigantes-tecnologicas-de-eeuu-ante-aranceles-de-trump)

**China Considers Antitrust Investigation into Intel**
The Financial Times reported on February 4 that China is considering launching an antitrust investigation into US chip manufacturer Intel. According to sources, China has restarted antitrust investigations into US companies Google and Nvidia, and is now considering a new investigation into Intel. The investigation's nature and whether it has been formally launched may be affected by the current state of China-US relations, as Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to speak with US President Trump in the near future. China is Intel's largest market, with sales of $15.5 billion in 2024, accounting for 29% of Intel's global revenue. Liu Xue, a special researcher at the National Strategy Research Institute of Tsinghua University, analyzed that this series of investigation actions 'may be part of China's retaliatory measures against Trump's new tariff measures.' Liu Xue also pointed out that using antitrust investigations as a tool for trade negotiations 'may not be the best way to protect Chinese companies that have been hit by US tariffs, and 'this will undoubtedly spark controversy.'
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2025 05:38 AM
Source:[std.stheadline.com](https://std.stheadline.com/realtime/article/2050949/%E5%8D%B3%E6%99%82-%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B-%E8%8B%B1%E5%AA%92%E6%8C%87%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B%E6%93%AC%E5%B0%8DIntel%E5%B1%95%E5%8F%8D%E5%A3%9F%E6%96%B7%E8%AA%BF%E6%9F%A5)

**China Launches Investigation into Google, Considers Intel as Next Target**
China's National Market Supervision Administration announced on April 18, 2024, that it will investigate Google for competition concerns, focusing on its dominance in the Android operating system and potential harm to Chinese smartphone manufacturers such as Oppo and Xiaomi. Sources indicate that the agency is also considering launching a formal investigation into Intel, following a similar probe into Nvidia in December last year. According to Liu Xue, a research fellow at the National Strategy Research Institute of Tsinghua University, the investigation into tech giants may be a response to US President Trump's new tariffs, a retaliatory measure. Liu said, 'Using anti-monopoly investigations as a tool for trade negotiations may not be the best way to protect Chinese companies from US tariffs, as it will inevitably spark controversy.' The US has imposed tariffs on Chinese products, and China has responded by investigating American tech companies, including Google and Nvidia. The investigation into Intel could lead to significant fines or loss of market access in the world's largest international market, where China accounts for 29% of Intel's global revenue.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2025 05:33 AM
Source:[東方網 馬來西亞東方日報](https://www.orientaldaily.com.my/news/business/2025/02/05/710382)

**China to Investigate Intel Amid Antitrust Probes into Google and NVIDIA**
According to Financial Times, the Chinese authorities, who have already started investigating NVIDIA and Google for antitrust violations, are also considering an investigation into Intel. The Chinese National Market Regulation Administration announced today that it has started an antitrust investigation into Google, focusing on the company's dominance in the Android operating system and the harm caused to Chinese smartphone manufacturers such as Oppo and Xiaomi. This investigation was first initiated in 2019 but was put on hold for several years before being resumed in December 2024. The administration also started a similar investigation into NVIDIA in December 2024. An official investigation into Intel is also being considered, although the nature of the investigation and whether it will be launched are still unclear and may be influenced by US-China relations.
Original language: ko
Publish date: February 05, 2025 05:17 AM
Source:[기술로 세상을 바꾸는 사람들의 놀이터](https://it.chosun.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=2023092133502)

**China May Launch Antitrust Investigation into Intel Amid US-China Trade Tensions**
China may launch an antitrust investigation into Intel, following a similar probe into Google, according to a Financial Times report. The reasons for the investigation are unclear, but it is believed to be a retaliatory measure against the US for recent tariff increases. Unlike Google, which has limited business in China, an investigation into Intel could have a significant impact. China is Intel's largest market globally, and the company has faced challenges in recent years in product development and manufacturing. If Intel is caught in the middle of the US-China trade tensions, the situation could worsen.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2025 04:45 AM
Source:[Yahoo News (Taiwan)](https://tw.news.yahoo.com/china-may-probe-intel-for-antitrust-044351322.html)

**China Considers Investigation into Intel Amid Sino-US Trade Tensions**
According to the Financial Times, China is considering launching an investigation into US chip manufacturer Intel. A source said that the nature of the investigation is still unclear and may be affected by the Sino-US relationship, with Chinese President Xi Jinping expected to speak with US President Trump in the near future. China is Intel's largest market, with sales of $15.5 billion in 2024, accounting for 29% of its global revenue. Following the announcement of an antitrust investigation into Nvidia in December, China's State Administration for Market Regulation announced an investigation into Google on Tuesday. Liu Xue, a research fellow at the National Strategy Research Institute of Tsinghua University, said that these investigations 'may be part of China's retaliatory measures against Trump's new round of tariffs.' However, Liu added that using antitrust investigations as a tool for trade negotiations may not be the best way to protect Chinese companies hit by US tariffs, 'this will undoubtedly spark controversy.'
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2025 03:51 AM
Source:[早报](https://www.zaobao.com.sg/realtime/china/story20250205-5832168)

**China Considers Investigation into Intel Amid US-China Trade Tensions**
Following the US's imposition of tariffs on China, the Chinese government has taken action against American companies. The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) announced an antitrust investigation into Google, and the Financial Times reports that Intel may also face potential scrutiny. According to analysts, this move is a retaliatory measure against the US's comprehensive tariff increase. Sources close to the matter revealed that the focus of the investigation into Google will be on the company's Android operating system and the harm it has caused to Chinese smartphone manufacturers. One source stated that the Chinese government had previously launched a similar investigation into NVIDIA in December last year and is now considering launching a new investigation into Intel; however, the nature of the investigation and whether it has been launched may be affected by the current state of Sino-US relations. Dr. Liu Xue, a special researcher at the National Strategy Research Institute of Tsinghua University, believes that this investigation into American companies may be part of China's retaliation against the Trump administration's tariff increase. The two sources mentioned that China had first launched an investigation into Google in 2019, but it was put on hold for several years before being re-launched in December 2024. This move occurred before Trump's presidency, when Trump repeatedly threatened to impose high tariffs on Chinese goods during his presidential campaign. It was also revealed that before Trump took office, Chinese regulatory departments had visited Google's Beijing office, requesting relevant information. In December 2024, China also announced an investigation into NVIDIA. At the time, the outgoing Biden administration used its final months to strengthen controls on the export of advanced chips, attempting to hinder China's growing development of artificial intelligence. The Financial Times reports that antitrust investigations into American tech giants may result in fines related to global income or loss of market access in the world's largest international market, China. China is Intel's largest market, surpassing the US. Data shows that Intel's sales in China reached $15.5 billion in 2024, accounting for 29% of its global revenue.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2025 03:32 AM
Source:[UDN](https://udn.com/news/story/7333/8528235)

**China Considers Investigation into Intel Amid Rising Tech Scrutiny**
China is considering launching an investigation into Intel, following similar probes into Google and Nvidia. According to Liu Xue, a research fellow at the National Strategy Research Institute of Tsinghua University, this investigation 'may be part of China's retaliation against the Trump administration's tariffs on Chinese goods.' Intel's revenue in China has reached 29% of its global total, with the company's Chinese market share increasing by 4.6% in 2024. The investigation could lead to fines related to global income or loss of market access in China, one of the largest international markets for Intel. China has been increasing its scrutiny of foreign tech companies, with the National Market Supervision Administration announcing an antitrust investigation into Google in February and a similar probe into Nvidia in December 2024. 'The world is moving towards stricter antitrust regulation of big tech companies,' said Sun Nanxiang, a researcher at the International Law Institute of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. 'The core principle of antitrust is to use legal tools to maintain fair competition and enhance the international competitiveness of market entities.' 
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2025 03:17 AM
Source:[tmtpost.com](https://www.tmtpost.com/7442740.html)

**China Considers Antitrust Investigation into Intel as Retaliation for US Tariffs**
As a response to the new tariffs imposed by US President Trump, China is considering launching an antitrust investigation into Intel, according to sources. This move comes after China's antitrust regulators investigated NVIDIA and Google, and the latest target may be Intel. The Chinese National Market Supervision Administration announced on Tuesday that it will conduct a competition investigation into Google, focusing on its dominance in the Android operating system and any potential harm to Chinese smartphone manufacturers such as Oppo and Xiaomi. Two sources revealed that the same antitrust regulators who investigated NVIDIA in December are now considering launching a formal investigation into Intel. However, the sources noted that the nature of the investigation is still unclear and may be influenced by the current state of US-China relations. 'This may be a response to the new tariffs, and a way to retaliate,' said Liu Xu, a researcher at the National Strategy Research Institute of Tsinghua University. 'Using antitrust investigations as a tool for trade negotiations may not be the best way to protect Chinese companies from being hit by US tariffs,' Liu added. The investigation into Google was initially launched in 2019 but was put on hold for several years before being re-launched in December. China is Intel's largest market, surpassing the US, and the company's sales in China reached $15.5 billion in 2024, accounting for 29% of its global revenue.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2025 02:05 AM
Source:[自由時報電子報](https://ec.ltn.com.tw/article/breakingnews/4941573)

**China May Launch Antitrust Investigation into Intel**
According to the Financial Times, Chinese regulatory authorities may launch an antitrust investigation into Intel (INTC.US). The report suggests that the National Market Regulation Bureau of China is considering an investigation into Intel as a bargaining chip in negotiations with US President Trump. The potential investigation into Intel is part of a series of renewed antitrust investigations by the National Market Regulation Bureau, including those against Alphabet's (GOOGL.US) Google and NVIDIA (NVDA.US). The investigations are seen as a response to the escalation of Sino-US geopolitical tensions. 'The report indicates that China is using Intel as a bargaining chip in negotiations with the US,' said an analyst. 'This is a clear sign that China is willing to take a tougher stance in its dealings with the US.'

**China Considers Antitrust Investigation into Intel Amid US-China Trade Tensions**
China's State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) is considering launching an antitrust investigation into US chip giant Intel, according to the Financial Times. This potential investigation is part of China's broader response to the US government's recent decision to impose new tariffs on Chinese goods. SAMR has already re-launched an antitrust investigation into Google in December, focusing on whether the Android operating system has harmed Chinese smartphone manufacturers such as Oppo and Xiaomi. The agency is now weighing whether to officially launch an investigation into Intel, but details of the potential investigation remain unclear. The decision may depend on the state of US-China relations in the coming weeks, as Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to hold talks with US officials on trade and economic policy. Additionally, SAMR has begun an antitrust investigation into Nvidia, examining potential violations related to its 2019 acquisition of Israeli network company Mellanox Technologies. 'This will inevitably lead to disputes,' said Lu Xiu, a researcher at the National Institute of Strategy at Tsinghua University, commenting on the use of antitrust investigations as a countermeasure in trade disputes.

**China to Launch Antitrust Investigation into Google, Considers Intel Probe**
According to the Financial Times, China's National Market Supervision Administration has announced the launch of an antitrust investigation into Google, focusing on the company's dominant position in the Android operating system and potential harm to Chinese smartphone manufacturers such as Oppo and Xiaomi. The investigation is part of China's efforts to negotiate with US President Trump, seeking leverage in their talks. China is also considering launching a formal investigation into Intel, following a similar investigation into NVIDIA last December. However, the nature of the potential investigation into Intel remains unclear, and may be influenced by the current state of US-China relations. 'The investigation into Intel is still under consideration, and its outcome may depend on the outcome of the upcoming talks between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Trump,' said a source. 'China is seeking to use these investigations as leverage in its negotiations with the US,' added another source. Source:[Udnemoney聯合理財網           ](https://money.udn.com/money/story/5599/8527539)

**China to Launch Antitrust Investigation Against Intel: A Response to US Tariffs**
Intel's stock price fell by 1.15% after a report by Financial Times that Chinese regulators may launch an antitrust investigation against the company. This could be another step by China in response to the US administration's decision to impose higher tariffs on Chinese imports. The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) has been responding to the escalation of geopolitical tensions between China and the US. The potential investigation into Intel is part of a broader trend of antitrust investigations into many large American technology companies. SAMR has recently resumed a previously frozen investigation into Google's dominance of the Android operating system, which affected many Chinese smartphone manufacturers, such as Oppo and Xiaomi. The company has also recently launched an investigation into Nvidia, and today there are reports of another antitrust investigation into Google. The nature and scope of the investigation into Intel remain unclear, and depend on the future development of relations between the US and China. The timing and scope of the investigation may be influenced by the upcoming conversation between Chinese leader Xi Jinping and US President Trump. The decline in Intel's stock price reflects investors' concerns about the potential impact of a Chinese regulator's investigation on the company's operations on the significant Chinese market for semiconductor companies. As Xi Jinping said, 'The Chinese government will take all necessary measures to protect the interests of Chinese companies.' 
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 04, 2025 02:55 PM
Source:[3DNews - Daily Digital Digest](https://3dnews.ru/1117723/aktsii-intel-podesheveli-na-fone-vozmognogo-kitayskogo-antimonopolnogo-rassledovaniya-v-otnoshenii-kompanii)

**Intel Faces Possible Investigation in China Amid US-China Trade Tensions**
Following US President Trump's decision to impose a 10% tariff on Chinese goods, Beijing has taken retaliatory measures. In addition to launching an antitrust investigation into Google, China is reportedly targeting US chipmaker Intel. According to the Financial Times, citing sources, Chinese regulators are evaluating whether to formally launch an investigation into Intel, but the type of investigation is still unknown. Sources say that whether China will formally investigate Intel depends on the state of US-China relations, as Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to meet with Trump in the coming days. China is Intel's largest market, surpassing the US. According to filing documents, Intel's revenue in China reached $15.5 billion in 2024, accounting for 29% of its global revenue. Intel has not responded to a request for comment.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 04, 2025 02:14 PM
Source:[Udnemoney聯合理財網           ](https://money.udn.com/money/story/5599/8527346)

**Intel Faces Possible Investigation in China Amid US-China Tensions**
Following US President Trump's decision to impose a 10% tariff on Chinese goods, the Chinese government has taken retaliatory measures. In addition to launching an antitrust investigation into Google, China is reportedly targeting US chipmaker Intel. According to the Financial Times, citing sources, Chinese regulatory bodies are currently evaluating whether to formally launch an investigation into Intel, but the type of investigation is still unknown. Sources indicate that whether China will formally launch an investigation into Intel may depend on the state of US-China relations, as Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to meet with Trump in the coming days. China is Intel's largest market, surpassing the US. According to filing documents, Intel's revenue in China reached $15.5 billion in 2024, accounting for 29% of its global revenue. Intel has not yet responded to a request for comment.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 04, 2025 02:13 PM
Source:[UDN](https://udn.com/news/story/6813/8527346)

Given China's strategic goals to become less dependent on foreign technology, an antitrust investigation can serve as a tool to promote domestic players while keeping an essential foreign entity in check.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Ongoing U.S.-China tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The geopolitical tensions between the U.S. and China still persist, and using regulatory measures such as antitrust investigations could also be a geopolitical signal related to broader trade or geopolitical negotiations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Intel's compliance and cooperation
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Intel is seen as compliant and cooperative with Chinese market regulations, the likelihood of an investigation might be lower. However, evidence for significant new compliance gestures from Intel specific to China's market isn't apparent recently.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple sources indicate that China is considering or has already commenced similar antitrust investigations into other major U.S. tech companies like Google and Nvidia, as part of broader geopolitical tensions. This context makes it highly plausible that Intel is similarly targeted. The Financial Times and other credible sources actively report China's consideration of an Intel investigation as part of its strategic positioning against U.S. tariffs, highlighting that Intel is notably one of the largest foreign players in the Chinese market.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The rumors of Intel forming a joint venture with Taiwan’s TSMC could potentially align Intel more closely with U.S. government strategies, hence possibly reducing China's immediate incentive to disrupt Intel's operations. However, this point is weaker compared to the weight of existing geopolitical tensions.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, China has launched significant antitrust investigations into foreign technology companies, especially in response to perceived dominance that might affect local competition. Over the past decade, there have been approximately 2-3 notable cases per year involving global firms, although not all of these have been directed at a single major company like Intel. In the first quarter of the year, adjustments to strategic decisions or regulatory actions occur regularly, influenced by economic and political considerations. Given this context, an initial base rate for a notable market intervention such as an antitrust investigation against a major tech company could be estimated around 15%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Market Share Concerns
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Intel's dominance in the semiconductor industry might trigger scrutiny from Chinese regulators aimed at fostering local competition, especially in sectors linked to domestic technology advancements.

perspective_derived_factors.name: China's Regulatory Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China has been increasingly proactive in enforcing antitrust measures against foreign entities to ensure fair market practices and bolster domestic technological development. Recent trends indicate a likelihood of action due to regulatory tightening.

perspective_derived_factors.name: US-China Relations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The geopolitical tensions between the US and China can influence the decision to investigate large American firms, possibly using antitrust actions as a tool for economic negotiation. Current tensions suggest an increase in the probability of such actions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous Investigation Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Previous investigations into foreign firms have sometimes followed a pattern where China uses these actions to exert pressure, signaling regulation while pushing for better terms in trade or tech collaboration agreements.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several articles explicitly state that China is considering launching an antitrust investigation into Intel. News sources indicate this potential investigation is a strategic move in the context of US trade tensions, supporting the possibility of such an action. China's recent actions against American tech firms, including Google and Nvidia, and retaliatory measures against US tariffs reinforce the likelihood of a broader strategic approach, which includes Intel.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite multiple reports indicating potential scrutiny, it is consistently emphasized that a formal investigation into Intel has not yet been officially launched, and its initiation could depend on evolving Sino-US relations. Any shifts toward stabilization in US-China relations might delay or prevent the formal initiation.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Based on historical data, China's antitrust investigations into major foreign technology companies have occurred periodically, often aligning with broader geopolitical tensions or when the companies hold significant market power in China. Between 2010 and 2023, there have been at least two such major investigations each year targeting different technology sectors. Given these historical trends, I would assign an initial base rate probability of around 10% for any individual major foreign tech firm, like Intel, to be investigated within a three-month period.

perspective_derived_factors.name: US-China Tech Tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given the current geopolitical climate, with increased tensions between the US and China particularly in the technology sector, the likelihood of China leveraging antitrust investigations as a tool to counterbalance US influence is heightened. This is especially relevant as Intel is a significant player in the semiconductor industry, a key area of focus in US-China tech relations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: China's Domestic Semiconductor Goals
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China has been heavily investing in bolstering its domestic semiconductor capabilities as part of its Made in China 2025 initiative. An investigation into a major foreign semiconductor company like Intel could serve to strategically alleviate competitive pressures on domestic firms and support national interests.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Regulatory Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent patterns of Chinese regulatory actions indicate increased scrutiny on foreign firms, particularly in the technology sector. If there have been recent signs of regulatory tightening or similar actions against industry peers, this would increase the probability.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news articles indicate that China has already launched or is considering launching antitrust investigations into major US tech firms such as Nvidia and Google, and that Intel is also under consideration for such an investigation. This confirms the geopolitical strategy of using antitrust measures as a response to US tariffs.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: While Intel is a significant player affected by US-China trade tensions, no formal decision has been announced yet, and there is an indication that these decisions may be used as leverage in negotiations with the US, implying that an announcement might depend on the evolution of these talks.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, China has launched antitrust investigations into foreign companies, including US tech companies, as part of its regulatory framework and in response to broader geopolitical tensions. Examining past data, China appears to have conducted such investigations at a moderate frequency over the past decade, roughly once a year on average in the context of larger geopolitical disputes or market dominance issues. Given the ongoing pattern of trade tensions and regulatory scrutiny globally, particularly towards tech companies, we can set an initial probability base rate at about 25%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: US-China Tech Rivalry
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The geopolitical rivalry between the US and China has intensified with increasing focus on technology and microchip industries. Intel, as a major player in this space, is significantly impacted by US policies aimed at limiting China's technological growth. This rivalry and pressure on tech dominance incentivizes China to scrutinize companies like Intel more closely.

perspective_derived_factors.name: China's Antitrust Regulatory Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China's commitment to tightening its regulatory framework, particularly in antitrust actions, increases the likelihood of investigations. Recent legislative changes and investigations against various tech giants demonstrate China's active stance in maintaining market order and competitive fairness.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Interdependence
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Despite geopolitical tensions, there remains a strong economic interdependence between the US and China, particularly concerning tech industries. This mutual economic reliance might temper more aggressive regulatory actions to avoid escalation that could adversely affect economic interests.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Recent news confirms China has reopened its antitrust investigations into other major US tech companies like Google and NVIDIA, as part of broader retaliatory measures in response to US tariffs. This demonstrates China's willingness to use regulatory scrutiny as leverage in trade disputes, suggesting Intel might be similarly targeted.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The potential joint venture between Intel and TSMC, and the involvement of significant US government interest in maintaining domestic chip production, might complicate or delay China's decision to launch an antitrust investigation against Intel. Furthermore, an actual investigation into Intel has not yet been confirmed or formally announced.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, China has initiated antitrust investigations into foreign companies when there were concerns about monopolistic behaviors or to exert negotiating leverage in broader trade tensions. Given this frequency, there's a base rate of roughly 20% for any specific quarter seeing such a new investigation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: US-China Trade Relations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent months have seen a decline in US-China tensions following diplomatic engagements. A stable or improving trade relationship typically reduces the likelihood of China launching aggressive trade measures like antitrust investigations. Thus, this factor decreases the probability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: China's Domestic Market Priorities
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China has been focusing on boosting its domestic semiconductor industry as part of its technological self-reliance strategy. Applying pressure on Intel could be seen as an opportunity to promote local companies. This increases the likelihood of an investigation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Regulatory Activity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China's regulatory bodies have recently been focusing more on internal companies violating antitrust laws rather than foreign entities, suggesting a strategic shift in priorities. This indicates a lowered likelihood of targeting foreign companies like Intel at this time.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Articles indicate that China is already considering an investigation into Intel as part of broader retaliatory measures against US tariffs, aligning with previous indications of China using antitrust investigations as tools in trade disputes.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The new information shows a strong and active consideration by China to launch an investigation into Intel due in part to trade tensions heightened by recent US tariffs. This strengthens the potential likelihood of an investigation.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Looking at historical data, China has initiated antitrust investigations into large tech companies when perceived as a threat to local businesses or when political and economic tensions with the U.S. rise. perspective_derived_factors.name: U.S.-China Technological Tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Heightened tensions between the U.S. and China over technology and trade policies have often led to increased regulatory scrutiny of U.S. companies operating in China. perspective_derived_factors.name: China's Economic Slowdown
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: With China's economy experiencing slower growth rates, there is a priority on strengthening domestic industries. Investigations into foreign companies can be strategic moves to shift focus to domestic firms. This context increases the probability of an antitrust probe as China seeks to bolster its own tech giants.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Antitrust Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China has recently been more aggressive in enforcing antitrust laws, as seen in their actions against domestic and foreign firms alike. This trend supports a higher probability for initiating new investigations, aligning with the broader regulatory strategy.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several reports confirm China's intention to use antitrust investigations as retaliatory measures against US tariffs and indicate a potential investigation into Intel. forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, China has launched antitrust investigations into foreign technology companies, especially those with significant market power. perspective_derived_factors.name: US-China Tech Tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The ongoing tech rivalry between the US and China increases the likelihood of regulatory actions being used to constrain US companies. Intel, being a major US technology firm, may face increased scrutiny as a result of these tensions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: China's Regulatory Focus on Semiconductors
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China's strategic emphasis on developing its own semiconductor industry heightens the possibility of targeting foreign semiconductor companies. An investigation into Intel may align with China's goal to promote domestic players.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous Antitrust Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China has a history of fluctuating antitrust enforcement; while some years see significant activity, others do not. Given the lack of recent high-profile investigations, there might be a cooldown period, reducing the likelihood of a new investigation.

perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: In efforts to maintain economic stability, China may avoid hasty investigations into key international players like Intel, which play a crucial role in global supply chains.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent geopolitical tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There has been an increase in geopolitical tensions between the US and China. Given that Intel is a major US technology company, these tensions heighten China's incentive to scrutinize US firms more closely, possibly leading to antitrust actions.

perspective_derived_factors.name: China's focus on tech self-reliance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China is currently emphasizing self-reliance in semiconductor technology, as outlined in its recent five-year plans. perspective_derived_factors.name: Intel's business practices in China
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Intel has been engaging in practices that could be deemed anti-competitive, such as exclusive agreements or aggressive pricing tactics within China, this would increase the likelihood of an antitrust investigation. perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous antitrust investigations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: China has shown a pattern of focusing on specific industries (like tech) for antitrust probes when aligning with broader governmental priorities. revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several articles suggest that China is actively considering launching an antitrust investigation into Intel as part of its retaliatory measures against the US's tariff policies. The SAMR has already initiated similar investigations against Google and Nvidia, indicating a pattern that could logically extend to Intel. Intel's significant market share in China (29% of its global revenue) makes it a likely target for such investigations, given the leverage it offers China in trade negotiations with the US.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: While numerous sources indicate China's intention to possibly investigate Intel, none confirm that a formal investigation has definitely been launched.
